chapterTitle: Some Lessons From Capital Market History

columns.text: In this problem, we will use Blume's formula to estimate the average rate of return for different time ranges.
Based on the 91-year averages, we have an arithmetic average of $12\%$ and geometric average of $10\%$.

Solving for the average rate of return over $5$ years:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Rate}&=\dfrac{5-1}{91-1}\times10+\dfrac{91-5}{91-1}\times 12\\[15 pt]
&=11.91
\end{aligned}$$

The average rate of return over $5$ years is $11.91\%$

Solving for the average rate of return over $10$ years:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Rate}&=\dfrac{10-1}{91-1}\times10+\dfrac{91-10}{91-1}\times 12\\[15 pt]
&=11.80
\end{aligned}$$

The average rate of return over $10$ years is $11.80\%$

Solving for the average rate of return over $20$ years:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Rate}&=\dfrac{20-1}{91-1}\times10+\dfrac{91-20}{91-1}\times 12\\[15 pt]
&=11.58
\end{aligned}$$

The average rate of return over $20$ years is $11.58\%$

Solving for the average rate of return over $40$ years:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Rate}&=\dfrac{40-1}{91-1}\times10+\dfrac{91-40}{91-1}\times 12\\[15 pt]
&=11.13
\end{aligned}$$

The average rate of return over $40$ years is $11.13\%$
In this problem, we will use Blume's Formula to get the best estimate return for large-company stocks.

Let's first define what is Blume's formula.

**Blume's Formula** combines both arithmetic and geometric returns to estimate future yearly returns, so removing their long- and short-term limitations.  It's a basic formula that takes into account the stock's entire life span and the expected return for the stock in the future.

***How we can calculate the Blume's formula?***

The general equation for Blume's formula is as follows:

$$\text{R(T)}=\dfrac{\text{T}-1}{\text{N}-1}\cdot\text{GAR}+\dfrac{\text{N}-\text{T}}{\text{N}-1}\cdot\text{AAR}$$

**Where:**

R(T) - the annual returns

N - the number of periods

GAR - the geometric average return 

T - the number of observed years to estimate the return

AAR - the arithmetic average return

Using the data from Table 12.4 of the book, we can determine that the time span between 1926 and 2019 (which includes both years) is 94 years. The result of this calculation represents a number of periods.
Now we will identify the given amounts in a problem:

| | Amount/Value| 
|--|--| 
|Arithmetic average return| 12.1%| 
|Geometric average return  |10.2% | 
| Number of observed years| 1, 10, 20, 40 years| 
| Number of periods| 94 years |

First, we will find the the best estimated return for large-company stocks over the next year. Substituting known values into equation from step 3, we get:

$$\begin{align*}
\text{R(T)}&=\dfrac{\text{T}_1-1}{\text{N}-1}\cdot\text{GAR}+\dfrac{\text{N}-\text{T}_1}{\text{N}-1}\cdot\text{AAR}\\[15pt]
&=\dfrac{1-1}{94-1}\cdot10.2\%+\dfrac{94-1}{94-1}\cdot12.1\%\\[15pt]
&=\dfrac{0}{93}\cdot0.102+\dfrac{93}{93}\cdot0.121\\[15pt]
&=0+1\cdot0.121\\[10pt]
&=0.121\\[10pt]
&=12.1\%
\end{align*}$$

Therefore, the best estimate of the future annual returns for large-company stocks over the next year is **12.1%.**

Now, we will find the best estimated return for large-company stocks over the 10 years by using the same equation from step 3, as follows:

$$\begin{align*}
\text{R(T)}&=\dfrac{\text{T}_{10}-1}{\text{N}-1}\cdot\text{GAR}+\dfrac{\text{N}-\text{T}_{10}}{\text{N}-1}\cdot\text{AAR}\\[15pt]
&=\dfrac{10-1}{94-1}\cdot10.2\%+\dfrac{94-10}{94-1}\cdot12.1\%\\[15pt]
&=\dfrac{9}{93}\cdot0.102+\dfrac{84}{93}\cdot0.121\\[15pt]
&=0.0099+0.1093\\[10pt]
&=0.119\\[10pt]
&=11.9\%
\end{align*}$$

Therefore, the best estimate of the future annual returns for large-company stocks over the 10 years is **11.9%.**

Now, we will find the best estimated return for large-company stocks over the 20 years by using the same equation from step 3, as follows:

$$\begin{align*}
\text{R(T)}&=\dfrac{\text{T}_{20}-1}{\text{N}-1}\cdot\text{GAR}+\dfrac{\text{N}-\text{T}_{20}}{\text{N}-1}\cdot\text{AAR}\\[15pt]
&=\dfrac{20-1}{94-1}\cdot10.2\%+\dfrac{94-20}{94-1}\cdot12.1\%\\[15pt]
&=\dfrac{19}{93}\cdot0.102+\dfrac{74}{93}\cdot0.121\\[15pt]
&=0.0208+0.0963\\[10pt]
&=0.117\\[10pt]
&=11.7\%
\end{align*}$$

Therefore, the best estimate of the future annual returns for large-company stocks over the 20 years is **11.7%.**

Now, we will find the best estimated return for large-company stocks over the 40 years by using the same equation from step 3, as follows:

$$\begin{align*}
\text{R(T)}&=\dfrac{\text{T}_{40}-1}{\text{N}-1}\cdot\text{GAR}+\dfrac{\text{N}-\text{T}_{40}}{\text{N}-1}\cdot\text{AAR}\\[15pt]
&=\dfrac{40-1}{94-1}\cdot10.2\%+\dfrac{94-40}{94-1}\cdot12.1\%\\[15pt]
&=\dfrac{39}{93}\cdot0.102+\dfrac{54}{93}\cdot0.121\\[15pt]
&=0.0428+0.0703\\[10pt]
&=0.113\\[10pt]
&=11.3\%
\end{align*}$$

Therefore, the best estimate of the future annual returns for large-company stocks over the 40 years is **11.3%.**

**Let's recap what we have done.**

Firstly, we have identified what is Blume's Formula and how we can calculate it.

Secondly, we've substituted given values in the Blume's Formula calculated the best estimate of the future annual returns for large-company stocks over the next year, 10 years, 20 years, and 40 years.

Lastly, we fount that the best estimate of the future annual returns for large-company stocks over the next year is 12.1%; over the 10 years is 11.9%; over the 20 years is 11.7%; over the 40 years is 11.3%.
